properties.Name: BeneficiaryType
properties.Description:
A means of typing or categorizing Beneficiaries by common characteristics.

Ex:
- Absolute Beneficiary
- Business Beneficiary
- Charity Beneficiary
- Class Beneficiary
- Estate Beneficiary
- Individual Beneficiary
- Minor Beneficiary
- Trust Beneficiary

ABSOLUTE BENEFICIARY
A beneficiary that cannot be changed without his consent.

BUSINESS BENEFICIARY
A Business selected to be the  sole or proportional beneficiary of a life insurance policy.

CHARITY BENEFICIARY
Life insurance is a means of contributing to a charity such as a church, educational institution, hospital etc. 

A contribution of life insurance proceeds cannot be contested by disgruntled heirs.  Life insurance proceeds are not part of the  insured-donor's probate estate.

CLASS BENEFICIARY
A 'class' or grouping is selected to be the  sole or proportional beneficiary of a life insurance policy.  

For example, "my children", "my family"

ESTATE BENEFICIARY
An Estate selected to be the  sole or proportional beneficiary of a life insurance policy.

Policyowners can designate that their estates are to be the  beneficiary.   In this case, upon their death the  proceeds can be used to meet federal estate taxes, debts and other administrative costs thus leaving other assets intact to pass on to heirs.   Leaving proceeds to an estate means that the  value of the  policy will be included in the  insured's total estate for tax purposes.

INDIVIDUAL BENEFICIARY
An individual selected to be the  sole or proportional beneficiary of a life insurance policy.

There may be one or more individual named as beneficiary.

MINOR BENEFICIARY
A Minor selected to be the  sole or proportional beneficiary of a life insurance policy.

Contingencies may be made to:

- Make limited payments to an adult guardian for the  benefit of the  minor
- Retain policy proceeds at interest and pay them at some future age or date
- Place proceeds in a trust for the  present or future benefit of the  minor

TRUST BENEFICIARY
A Trust that has purchased or has purchased on their behalf in an Insurance Product.

A Trust is a legal arrangement for the  ownership of property by one party for the  benefit of another. Assigning a Trust as the  beneficiary of a life insurance policy means that the  proceeds will be paid to the  trust for the  ultimate benefit and use of another party.

Columns.Name: BeneficiaryTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Beneficiary Type.

Columns.Name: BeneficiaryTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of the Beneficiary Type.

Columns.Name: BeneficiaryTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Beneficiary Type.
